journal-meta.journal-title: Journal of Reinforced Plastics and Composites

title-group.article-title: Correlation of temperature dependences of macro- and micro-interfacial properties in carbon fiber/epoxy resin composite

article-meta.aff: Key Laboratory of Aerospace Materials and Performance (Ministry of Education), School of Materials Science and Engineering, Beihang University, Beijing, China

author-notes.corresp: Gu YZ, School of Materials Science and Engineering, Beihang University, Xueyuan Road No. 37, Haidian District, Beijing 100191, PR China. Email: benniegu@buaa.edu.cn

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2013 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: The short beam shear test and single fiber fragmentation test with an energy-based model were conducted to characterize the interfacial properties of two types of carbon fiber–reinforced epoxy resin composites. The temperature dependences of interlaminar shear strength and interfacial fracture energy (Γi) from room temperature to 130°C were investigated. The correlation between interlaminar shear strength and the micro-interfacial property at elevated temperature was discussed. The scanning electron microscope images of fractographic cross-sections of the composite laminates were used to analyze the failure mode transition as the temperature rising. The results show that the interfacial properties of the two carbon fiber composites with the same matrix are obviously different, especially at high temperature. The changes of interlaminar shear strength and interfacial fracture energy are different at elevated temperature, mainly ascribed to the different treating ways of thermal residual stress and matrix property in the two methods. The similar temperature sensitivities in the changes of Γi and the amount of matrix adhering on carbon fibers in the short beam shear failure images suggest the variations of the micro-interfacial properties in the short beam test as increasing temperature.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Carbon fiber (CF)-reinforced composites have been widely used in aircraft industries due to their light weight, superior mechanical performance and corrosion resistance. In such applications, the CF composites structures are usually subjected to a wide rage of temperatures in long-term service. The mechanical properties of polymer matrix and interphase in the CF composite may degrade with increasing temperature due to their polymeric compositions and structures. In addition, the structure and mechanical properties of fiber/polymer matrix interphase are of utmost importance, which determine the ability of transfer stress from the matrix to the fiber and strongly influence the performance of composite. Thus, the interfacial adhesion of the polymer composites is very important for evaluating their thermal stability.

The composite laminate tests and single fiber composite tests are the conventional methods to measure the interfacial properties of polymer composites. Koyanagi et al.1 employed the transverse tensile test to study the temperature dependence of CF/epoxy interface strength. Sun et al.2 investigated the temperature effect on the interlaminar shear strength (ILSS) of CF/bismaleimide composite using the short beam shear test (SBS). A series of single fiber composite tests, such as the single fiber fragmentation test (SFFT),3-6 the micro bonding test7 and a cruciform specimen method,8 have been also performed to obtain the temperature dependence of micro-interface properties. The composite laminate tests are widely used in the manufacture and design of composite materials due to the simple sample preparations and test procedures.9,10 On the other hand, more microscopic information about the interphase region, not only interfacial shear strength but also interfacial toughness and failure mode, can be obtained from the single fiber composite tests. These results are very useful for resin and fiber surface modification and micro-mechanical analysis. Then, to investigate the interfacial properties from the macro and micro aspects is significant for completely understanding the mechanical behavior of composites and designing the interphase.

The method for measuring interlaminar property of laminate and that for interfacial adhesion between fiber and matrix have been simultaneously conducted to investigate CF composites. Drzal et al.11,12 analyzed the relationship between fiber-matrix adhesion and composite mechanical properties. Huang et al.13,14 used microbonding test and short beam shear test to study the interfacial properties in different oxidation surface-treated CF composites. These works demonstrate that due to the same materials and curing process for the samples in composite laminate test and single fiber composite test, the comparison between macro- and micro-interfacial properties is feasible. Thus, the two methods can be further employed to research the thermal stability of interphase and the correlation of temperature dependence of macro- and micro-interfacial properties in CF/epoxy composite.

In this paper, the variations of ILSS and interfacial fracture energy derived from SFFT for CF/epoxy resin composites using two kinds of CF were investigated at elevated temperature, ranging from 25°C to 130°C. Comparing the two types of interfacial characteristics, the correlation of the macro- and micro-interfacial properties was discussed. In addition, the failure patterns of the interlaminar shear tests under different temperatures were further analyzed by means of scanning electron microscope (SEM) to understand the failure mechanism.

sec.title: Materials
sec.p:
Two types of CF supplied from Beijing institute of aeronautical materials (BIAM) were used, which were named CF-1 and CF-2, respectively. The sizing agents of the two CF were different, which has been confirmed by Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy in our previous work.6 The mechanical properties of them are listed in Table 1. The matrix used in SFFT was a kind of high-temperature cured epoxy resin, named 5228, which was also supplied by BIAM. The cure schedule for this epoxy resin was 1 h at 130°C, then 2 h at 180°C and 3 h at 190°C. The properties of cured epoxy resin are also given in Table 1. The unidirectional laminates of CF-1/5228 and CF-2/5228 with 2 mm thickness were supplied by BIAM and were manufactured using autoclave process with the same temperature cycle as that of the SFFT samples. Table 1.
Mechanical properties of carbon fiber (CF) and epoxy resin
Parameters CF-1 CF-2 Epoxy resin 5228
Tensile strength (MPa) 3800 3750 86
Young’s modulus(GPa) 250 230 3.5
Poisson’s ratio 0.2 0.2 0.35
Fiber radius (µm) 3.5 3.5 —
Thermal expansion coefficient CTE (10−6/°C) −0.5 −0.5 65
CTE: thermal expansion coefficient.

sec.title: SBS test procedure
sec.p: The test coupons (20 mm × 6 mm × 2 mm) used in the SBS test were cut from the unidirectional laminates. The SBS test was conducted on an Instron 3369 test apparatus using three points bending according to ASTM D2344. The test was performed with 2 mm/min testing speed. The test temperature was chosen as ambient temperature (25°C), 50°C, 80°C, 110°C and 130°C, controlled by an environment chamber with the error of ±2°C. The ILSS can be calculated by the following expression: (1)ILSS=3Pb4bh where Pb is the maximum failure load, b and h are the width and thickness of the sample, respectively.

sec.title: Characterization of interlaminar shear failure mode
sec.p: To analyze the failure mode of SBS test sample, the shear failure sections at each test temperature were examined by an JSM-5800 SEM (Hitachi) with the magnification of 2000 times. The surfaces of samples were sputter coated with a thin layer of gold for SEM observation.

sec.title: SFFT technique
sec.p: In this paper, interfacial fracture energy (Γi) calculated from the energy-based model (called WND model) was used for characterizing the micro-interfacial property using single-fiber composites. The interfacial fracture energy is derived from an energy balance equation and the Cox’s shear lag model, and the expressions are shown as follows.15 (2)Γi=σf∞2rf2EfLd[Ld2+1β-βEfrf216Gf]-rfΓf2Ld (3)β=1rf2GmEfln(rm/rf) where Ef is the Young’s modulus of the fiber, σf∞ is the far field fiber stress, Ld is the length of the interfacial debonding zone, Γf is the fiber fracture energy, rf is the radius of the fiber, rm is the effective radius of the matrix, Gf and Gm are the shear modulus of the fiber and matrix, respectively. The shear modulus G of the materials is equal to E/2(1 + μ), where μ is the Poisson’s ratio and E is the Young’s modulus of the materials.

The values of the parameters in WND model are shown in Table 1 and in reference6, except for σf∞ and Ld. Ld is measured by a polarizing micrograph at the moment of the first fiber break, and σf∞ includes three kinds of stresses, i.e. the applied tensile stress σf, the thermal residual stress σth and the imposed pre-stress σpre16 σf is equal to σmEf/Em or εmEf at the first fiber break, where εm is the matrix strain at the same moment and Em is the resin Young’s modulus. Unlike the calculation of the ILSS, the thermal residual stress is considered in the expression of Γi. And σth is equivalent to αm·ΔT·Ef, where αm is the thermal expansion coefficient (CTE) of the resin and ΔT is the difference between the curing temperature and the measuring temperature. The CTE of the CF is much lower than that of the matrix as shown in Table 1, so it is excluded in the calculation of σth. The pre-stress σpre is expressed as Fpre/πrf2, where Fpre is the constant applied load on the fiber to keep the fiber straight. Thus, σf∞ can be expressed as follows: (4)σf∞=σf+σth+σpre=ɛm·Ef+αm·ΔT·Ef+Fpreπrf2

The SFFT samples were dumbbell shaped and the sample dimension, preparation and test procedures are explicitly described in our precious work.6,17 The laboratory-made SFFT apparatus is shown in Figure 1. The testing temperatures, which were same as those in the SBS test, were controlled by a resistance wire heated box fixed on the SFFT apparatus. The temperature deviation was about ±1°C. The parameters, such as Ld and εm, were directly recorded by the SFFT apparatus. And the matrix modulus Em in each test temperature was obtained from the stress–strain curve. At least seven coupons were measured for each test temperature. Figure 1.
Sketch of single fiber fragmentation test (SFFT) apparatus.

sec.title: Temperature dependence of ILSS
sec.p:
The ILSS of CF-1/5228 and CF-2/5228 unidirectional laminates from ambient temperature to 130°C were measured by the SBS test. Figures 2 and 3 show the typical curves of the applied load as a function of displacement for the two studied composite materials at different temperature. The maximum failure loads for CF-1/5228 and CF-2/5228 composites decrease with increasing temperature. In each test temperature, the applied load values of CF-2/5228 coupons are greater than those of CF-1/5228 samples, indicating higher ILSS in the CF-2/5228 composite. Before reaching the load peak, the curve at 25°C is almost linear, while the other curves in Figures 2 and 3 firstly experience a linear stage, and then show a deviation from the linear behavior. The deviation in CF-1/5228 occurs earlier than that in CF-2/5228. The linear increase of load in both CF-1/5228 and CF-2/5228 composite is attributed to elastic behavior of the matrix and the interphase at lower load,18 while viscoelastic behavior of the matrix and the interphase at higher load can explain the deviation from the linear behavior.10 Because the failure load of CF-2/5228 sample is higher than that of CF-1/5228 sample at same test temperature, to reach the higher failure load, the curve of CF-2/5228 experiences longer time, which results in more obvious viscoelastic stage. Furthermore, since the matrix in the two composites is same, it also demonstrates that CF-2/5228 composite has a better interfacial adhesion than that of CF-1/5228. Figure 2.
Plots of applied load as a function of displacement for CF-1/5228 short beam shear test (SBS) test in various temperature.
Figure 3.
Plots of applied load as a function of displacement for CF-2/5228 short beam shear test (SBS) test in various temperature.

According to equation (1), the values of ILSS as a function of temperature are given in Figure 4. ILSS of CF-1/5228 and CF-2/5228 decrease as the temperature rises. At each test temperature, ILSS of CF-2/5228 is higher than that of CF-1/5228, demonstrating that the interfacial adhesion of CF-2/5228 is stronger than that of CF-1/5228 at elevated temperature. Figure 4.
Temperature dependence of interlaminar shear strength (ILSS) for CF-1/5228 and CF-2/5228 from ambient temperature to 130°C and their linear fit curves.

The change of ILSS with increasing temperature is almost linear, and the linear fit curves of the studied systems are also given in Figure 4. The correction coefficients, R2, of CF-1/5228 and CF-2/5228 in the linear fit curves are 0.987 and 0.998, respectively. Moreover, the fitting curve slopes of CF-1/5228 and CF-2/5228 are −0.415 and −0.303, respectively, indicating better heat-resisting of interfacial property for CF-2/5228.

sec.title: SBS test failure mode
sec.p:
The representative failure patterns for CF-1/5228 and CF-2/5228 at each test temperature were observed by SEM, as shown in Figures 5 and 6. Figure 5 clearly shows an interfacial dominating failure, because the fiber surfaces appear clean and without traces of matrix material adhering on them.11 Figure 6 shows matrix material still adhered to the fibers, so the failure mode is a matrix dominating failure.1 Thus, the interfacial adhesion of CF-2/5228 is stronger than that of CF-1/5228 at elevated temperature. At the high-rising temperature, the change of the matrix amount adhering on CFs is not obvious in both two composite samples. The results indicate that the interfacial bonding property may be insusceptible to temperature at the high temperature stage. It is inconsistent with the linear decrease of ILSS, possibly resulted from the difference between the micro- and macro-interfacial properties at elevated temperature. Thus, it is essential to investigate the temperature dependence of micro-interfacial property. Figure 5.
Scanning electron microscope (SEM) photos of fractographic cross-sections for CF-1/5228: (a) 25°C, (b) 50°C, (c) 80°C, (d)110°C, (e)130°C.
Figure 6.
Scanning electron microscope (SEM) photos of fractographic cross-sections for CF-2/5228: (a) 25°C, (b) 50°C, (c) 80°C, (d) 110°C, (e) 130°C.

sec.title: Interfacial fracture energy vs temperature
sec.p:
SFFT with an energy-based model was performed to analyze the micro-interfacial property. The interfacial fracture energies Γi versus temperature for CF-1/5228 and CF-2/5228 samples are shown in Figure 7. The Γi values of CF-1/5228 and CF-2/5228 decrease rapidly at initial rising temperature and reach a plateau at higher temperature. The results demonstrate that the interfacial property is sensitive to temperature at initial temperature rising and insensitive to temperature at high temperature. It was reported that the interfacial shear strength dropped near room temperature as increasing temperature using the SFFT method.3,5 It can be attributed to the existence of interphase with lower glass transition temperature (Tg) than the bulk matrix.3,5,19,20 At each test temperature, the Γi values of CF-2/5228 are higher than those of CF-1/5228, indicating that the CF-2/5228 composite has better micro-interfacial bonding property. The retention ratios of Γi at 130°C comparing to ambient temperature for CF-1/5228 and CF-2/5228 are 66.8% and 76.8%, respectively. Thus, the heat resistance of interphase of CF-2/5228 is better than that of CF-1/5228. Figure 7.
Variations of interfacial fracture energy at different temperature ranging from ambient temperature to 130°C.

sec.title: Correlation of ILSS and interfacial fracture energy
sec.p: As mentioned above, the ILSS and interfacial fracture energy of CF-2/5228 are higher than those of CF-1/5228 at the studied temperatures. And the heat resistance of interphase is better for CF-2/5228 than for CF-1/5228 by using the two methods. The interfacial bonding property of CF/epoxy resin composite can be affected by various factors, i.e. the mechanical property of matrix and fiber, the fiber surface topography, the type of fiber sizing agent and the composite curing process.13,14,21 In this work, the matrix and curing schedule are same in the laminate and single fiber composite, and the mechanical property and surface topography of two CFs are similar as described in our precious work.6 Thus, the different sizing agents on the two CFs, playing an important role in the formation of the CF reinforced composite interface, are the key factor to result in the different interfacial properties between the two studied composites. Our precious work proved that the interaction between the sizing and the matrix and the chain motion of the crosslink structure of the interphase determine the interfacial bonding property and the interfacial heat resistance.6

At elevated temperature, the variations of Γi in SFFT and the amount of matrix adhering on CFs in the SBS failure images are not distinct. It demonstrates that Γi and the failure mode are both insignificantly affected by temperature. These trends are different from the obvious linear decrease of ILSS. The results further imply that the micro-interfacial properties play an important role in the failure mode in the SBS test. On the other hand, the decrease trend of ILSS at elevated temperature is linear, which is quite different from that of Γi. Kar et al.22 considered that the decrease of ILSS with increasing temperature was attributed to the lower bonding strength of the matrix at high temperature, which softened gradually with increasing temperature. However, the variations of ILSS in the composites using the same epoxy resin matrix are distinct as shown in Figure 4. It demonstrates that the temperature dependence of ILSS depends on not only the matrix property but also the interphase performance. The matrix moduli Em at different temperatures are plotted in Figure 8. An approximately linear decrease of Em is shown as the temperature increases. It is a partial evidence of the linear decrease of ILSS at elevated temperature. Figure 8.
Matrix modulus as a function of temperature measured from single fiber fragmentation test (SFFT).

caption.p: Dependence of the interfacial fracture energy on the far field stress according to equations (2)–(4).

sec.p: The different change between macro- and micro-interfacial properties may relate to the different treating ways of the thermal residual stress and matrix mechanical property in the calculation of ILSS and Γi. ILSS is determined by the maximum failure load, and the effects of the matrix performance and thermal residual stress are implicit. For Γi, the matrix modulus and thermal residual stress are the input parameters according to equations (2)–(4). In equation (4), the thermal residual stress strongly influences the far field stress.

Figures 9 and 10 present the effects of the far field stress and matrix modulus on the interfacial fracture energy according to equations (2)–(4). The Γi values become higher with increasing σf∞ and decreasing Em, if other variables are constant. Thus, the variations of the two parameters will impact Γi significantly. Figure 10.
Dependence of the interfacial fracture energy on the matrix modulus according to equations (2)–(4).

The decrease of Em at the rising temperature (Figure 8) will result in the increase of Γi according to the dependence illustrated in Figure 10. The effect of the thermal residual stress on Γi is more complicated. The thermal residual stress exists when the samples are cooled down after the curing process due to the different CTEs of the fiber and the matrix. The thermal residual stress is usually compressive on the fiber at room temperature.23,24 When the temperature rises, the thermal residual stress lessens gradually, and the resin strain εm at the first fiber break changes. The resin strains at first fiber break with different temperatures for CF-1/5228 and CF-2/5228 samples are plotted in Figure 11. The εm values of two studied composite decline gradually as increasing temperature, which follow linear fit. The tensile stress to break fiber diminishes as the compressive thermal residual stress linearly decreases at elevated temperature. Then the fiber break appears in advance. Figure 11.
Resin strains at the first fiber break as a function of temperature for CF-1/5228 and CF-2/5228 composites measured from single fiber fragmentation test (SFFT).

The Γi values excluding the effects of the thermal residual stress and matrix modulus of CF-1/5228 and CF-2/5228 are plotted in Figure 12. Compared with Figure 7, the variation in Figure 12 becomes abrupt at high temperature, and the decrease trend is close to a linear reduction. Therefore, the differences in the considerations of the matrix property and the thermal residual stress at elevated temperature results in different temperature dependence of macro- and micro-interfacial properties. Figure 12.
Interfacial fracture energy excluding the effects of the thermal residual stress and matrix modulus as a function of temperature.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: The SBS test and SFFT with an energy-based model were employed to investigate the temperature dependence of interfacial properties for CF/epoxy composites from ambient temperature to 130°C. ILSS decreases linearly and Γi declines smoothly at elevated temperature for the two studied composites. The different treating ways of the thermal residual stress and matrix property result in the different temperature dependences of ILSS and Γi. In addition, the composite laminate test and single fiber composite test show the rank of the interfacial property for the two CF composites. Good interfacial adhesion and heat resistance of CF-2/epoxy resin are revealed, which are attributed to the effect of fiber sizing on the interphase. Moreover, the similar temperature sensitivities in the changes of Γi and the amount of matrix adhering on CFs in the SBS failure images at elevated temperature are demonstrated, indicating that the micro-interfacial property plays an important role in the mechanical behavior of laminates

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research was funded by the National Natural Science Fund Program of China (grant no. 51103003) and the National 973 Program of China (Project No. 2010CB631100).
